node.title: ‘The Odds Were Stacked Against Us’
node.alt: Kamah Asha Wilson, left, and Kelsey Reynolds were married Oct. 10 at Shirley Acres, an events space in Houston.
node.description: For Kelsey Reynolds and Kamah Asha Wilson, a “lesbian-queer, interracial, Christian couple,” marriage was an opportunity to embrace tradition on their terms.
node.content: ["Kelsey Reynolds and Kamah Asha Wilson call themselves \u201chopeful romantics.\u201d", "\u201cWe are a lesbian-queer, interracial, progressively Christian couple in the Deep South, from conservative families. The intersectional and circumstantial odds were stacked against us,\u201d said Mx. Reynolds, who is nonbinary and uses gender-neutral courtesy titles and pronouns.", "Ms. Wilson was facing an internal battle that \u201cwouldn\u2019t let me be with Kelsey without feeling like I was going to hell,\u201d she said, adding that she also struggled to overcome feelings of cultural betrayal \u201cby being with someone from a culture that has oppressed mine for hundreds of years.\u201d", "Mx. Reynolds, who attended private religious schools until college, said \u201cthere was a lot of indoctrination that I had to work through.\u201d They added, \u201cWe were in a really rough spot with our relationship toward the end of 2019 and were even questioning if we wanted to get married.\u201d", "Mx. Reynolds was raised Methodist and Ms. Wilson said she grew up \u201ccharismatic nondenominational, inside the umbrella of Pentecostist denomination; different from the Pentecostal religion, same root word.\u201d She added that, \u201cthough I am still a Pentecostist,\u201d both she and Mx. Reynolds now consider themselves nondenominational.", "The couple, who reside in Houston, met Jan. 21, 2013, as students in a human behavior course at Southeastern Louisiana University in Hammond, La. (Both are Louisiana natives; Mx. Reynolds, 30, is from Baton Rouge and Ms. Wilson, 30, is from Gonzales.) Mx. Reynolds sat diagonally in front of Ms. Wilson, who took notice of Mx. Reynolds\u2019s spirited disposition and budding relationship with one of her friends.", "\u201cIt was the perfect spot for me to watch Kelsey with intrigue. They were completely unaware that I existed,\u201d Ms. Wilson said. \u201cI was so annoyed by Kelsey\u2019s boisterous personality in the classroom and the fact that they were \u2018stealing\u2019 my best friend, Holly Edmondson.\u201d", "Over time, Ms. Wilson said her annoyance evolved into an appreciation for Mx. Reynolds\u2019s \u201cbig personality, humor and kindness.\u201d But months would pass before they actually \u201chad a proper conversation,\u201d she added. On April 22, 2013, the last day of class, they both \u201chung out\u201d with Ms. Edmondson at the campus library\u2019s cafe and the two exchanged numbers.", "The pair texted one another for a couple of weeks and then, Mx. Reynolds said, \u201cWe basically ghosted each other.\u201d But by the second week of fall semester, they had reconnected. \u201cI went from being annoyed to intrigued to friends to best friends to I want to kiss you now,\u201d Ms. Wilson said.", "Once they started dating in August 2013, Ms. Wilson and Mx. Reynolds said it wasn\u2019t long before each realized they had found something special in the other. The couple knew they had fallen in love, they said, in August 2014 while attending Glorieta Adventure Camp in Santa Fe, N.M., which incorporates Christian teachings into its camps and retreats.", "They were listening to \u201cNo Other Love\u201d by Chuck Prophet and looked into each other\u2019s eyes. Suddenly, Ms. Wilson found hers welling up with tears.", "\u201cI was overcome by silent but profound emotion,\u201d she said. \u201cI experienced such safety in that moment. I realized that this was love, and I wanted to look into their eyes, feel this way, be safe, held and wanted for the rest of my life.\u201d", "Ms. Wilson added that Mx. Reynolds was overcome with emotion as well. \u201cTheir eyes filled with tears and the next thing we knew, we were both sitting silent, with music filling the room, eyes locked on one another weeping. It was like we had a whole conversation.\u201d", "After graduating with bachelor\u2019s degrees from Southeastern Louisiana University, Ms. Wilson and Mx. Reynolds both earned master\u2019s degrees in social work from the University of Houston Graduate College of Social Work.", "Mx. Reynolds works as a volunteer services programs and engagement supervisor at the Houston Food Bank. Ms. Wilson, who lost her job because of the pandemic, is now focusing on growing her crafting business, the Doris & Dot Shoppe, for which she makes jewelry and home d\u00e9cor items.", "\u201cAfter being laid off during Covid, I\u2019ve been focusing on more creative work for the time being as I gently re-enter the work force,\u201d she said. \u201cI\u2019ve been recovering from severe chronic burnout.\u201d", "On March 18, 2017, the two were engaged when Ms. Wilson and Mx. Reynolds each surprised the other with a proposal on their college campus. \u201cIt was spring break and we went back specifically for me to propose, but Kamah didn\u2019t know until the day of,\u201d said Mx. Reynolds, whose proposal involved a scavenger hunt.", "Friends of the couple delivered Ms. Wilson the hunt\u2019s first clue. \u201cCome to the classroom where our minds first met,\u201d it read. When Ms. Wilson arrived at the location, she found another clue: \u201cCome to the tree where our lives intertwined like its roots.\u201d A third \u2014 \u201cCome to where Aslan lives\u201d \u2014 awaited her there.", "The last clue \u2014 \u201cCome to the garden where our souls first met\u201d \u2014 led Ms. Wilson to Tinsley Gardens, on the grounds of Southeastern Louisiana University. She arrived to find \u201cDear True Love\u201d by Sleeping at Last, one of the couple\u2019s favorite songs, playing, along with a roving photographer and some friends who were in on the plan.", "On the ground was a path of rose petals that turned into a heart, at the center of which stood Mx. Reynolds, who read Ms. Wilson a love letter and asked her to marry them.", "But Ms. Wilson did not simply say yes, as Mx. Reynolds expected.", "Instead, she said, \u201cI will if you say yes, too.\u201d Confused, Mx. Reynolds watched as Ms. Wilson rummaged through her bag, where an engagement ring for Mx. Reynolds had been waiting in case of this very moment.", "\u201cIt was better than the movies,\u201d Ms. Wilson said.", "The couple chose Oct. 11, 2020, as their original wedding date. \u201cThat day is both National Coming Out Day and the anniversary of when we both said those big three words,\u201d Mx. Reynolds said. But because of the pandemic, they postponed the date by almost one year exactly.", "On Oct. 10, they were wed in the garden at Shirley Acres, an events space in Houston. Mx. Reynolds\u2019s uncle, Benjamin Thomas Lawson Jr., who was ordained through the Universal Life Church for the event, officiated. The 120 guests, most of whom were vaccinated, included Mx. Reynolds\u2019s parents and paternal grandmother and Ms. Wilson\u2019s mother.", "Ms. Wilson\u2019s father and other family members declined to attend.", "\u201cMany of my family members weren\u2019t present because they have made it clear that this union is against God and is illegitimate. Many friends who used to be core figures and support systems in my life disconnected too,\u201d Ms. Wilson said.", "Ms. Wilson wore a gown made of organza and French tulle with lace appliqu\u00e9s and a scalloped-edge veil decorated with pearls. She carried a bouquet wrapped in \u201cmy late grandmother Doris\u2019s white gloves fastened by a few of her lapel pins,\u201d she added. \u201cMy grandmother Marion\u2019s lapel pin was also fastened to it.\u201d Mx. Reynolds donned a bespoke three-piece green suit.", "While neither of them is Jewish, the couple included a ketubah signing as part of the ceremony. \u201cThe Christian faith comes from a Hebrew history. I wanted to honor that with a ketubah, a contract between us and God,\u201d Ms. Wilson said. \u201cA marriage license is between us and the government.\u201d They also signed a Bible inscribed with their names and family tree at the wedding.", "Mx. Reynolds added that \u201cwe asked our guests, as our village, for a vow of support, which we already know we have, but how sweet to have it on camera.\u201d", "Instead of hyphenating or taking one or the other\u2019s last name, the couple chose to create a new one of their own. They came up with Lovelle. \u201cOur heart\u2019s desire was something unique, nearly unheard-of, with deep meaning, and something that meant or translated to \u2018love,\u2019\u201d Mx. Reynolds said. \u201cThe heart of the name is love.\u201d", "At the reception, a four-layer wedding cake with four different flavors and fillings was served. The couple also had a cake pull. \u201cIt\u2019s a Southern tradition. You attach ribbons to charms and each person pulls out a ribbon and the charm is your fortune or your omen. It\u2019s a very Louisiana thing,\u201d Ms. Wilson said. ", "Ms. Wilson also presented a gift to Mx. Reynolds, who is Irish and Scottish, that celebrated their family history: A souvenir plot of land in the Slievekirk Wood reserve in Ardmore, Ireland, which came with an honorary title. \u201cWhen you own the land, you become a lord or lady. We are now Lord and Lady of Ardmore,\u201d Ms. Wilson said.", "Their second-to-last dance was a New Orleans style Second Line that brought all of the guests to their feet. \u201cEven the waitstaff was dancing,\u201d Ms. Wilson said. Attendees cleared the floor as the Second Line ended, leaving the couple to have a last dance together to \u201cDear True Love,\u201d the song playing when they were engaged.", "As Ms. Wilson and Mx. Reynolds exited the venue, guests waved ribbon wands with bells attached to the ends. \u201cIt was pretty magical to see the ribbons waving and hear the bells tinkling,\u201d Ms. Wilson said. \u201cAnd to hear everyone chanting, \u2018Lovelle at last.\u2019\u201d", "When Oct. 10, 2021", "Where Shirley Acres, Houston", "Planting Roots During the ceremony, the couple transplanted a Magnolia tree from a nursery pot into a new pot with dirt from the backyards of their loved ones. \u201cIt\u2019s the state flower of Louisiana, where we\u2019re both from,\u201d Ms. Wilson said. \u201cIt represents perseverance, longevity, and all of those things you want in a relationship.\u201d", "Mothers\u2019 Day Instead of the traditional father-daughter dance, the couple had mother-daughter dances at their reception. Mx. Reynolds jitterbugged with their mother to \u201cMom\u201d by Meghan Trainor \u201cbecause she taught me how to jitterbug,\u201d they said. Ms. Wilson danced with her mother to \u201cPhenomenal\u201d by Benjai. \u201cWe would dance around the house to it to put us in a good mood,\u201d she said."]
